newsitem.title: HUNGARY: CSFB expects 10 pct Hungary inflation end '98.
newsitem.headline: CSFB expects 10 pct Hungary inflation end '98.

text.p: CS First Boston said inflation in Hungary should drop to 10 percent by end-1998 and that a reported more radical plan by the central bank to hit eight percent would be subject to compromise.

In a research report, CSFB said that according to unconfirmed press reports, the National Bank of Hungary is proposing to reach a lower inflation target by reducing wage growth to 10 percent and cutting the forint's crawling peg devaluator to zero in that year.
"The likely outcome is a compromise," CSFB said. "We continue to expect 10 percent inflation by end-1998, together with a monthly 0.5 percent crawling peg.
"This debate between the central bank and the Finance Ministry is not likely to affect this year's policies," it added.
Hungary's crawling peg devaluator now stands at 1.2 percent a month.

The government has targeted five percentage point cuts in average inflation in 1997 and 1998 from the 23.6 percent rate of 1996, but is under pressure from the International Monetary Fund to adopt a more ambitious plan.
